posts.title: Building Resumey.Pro: Lessons from My First SaaS
posts.excerpt: After quitting my job to build a resume builder, here are the key lessons I learned about product development, user feedback, and entrepreneurship.
posts.content:
# Building Resumey.Pro: Lessons from My First SaaS

After spending years in traditional design roles, I made the leap to build my own product. Resumey.Pro started as a simple idea: what if creating a professional resume could be as easy as filling out a form?

## The Journey

The development process taught me several key lessons:

### 1. Start with the Problem
I spent too much time on features nobody asked for. The real breakthrough came when I started talking to users daily.

### 2. Design Systems Matter
Building a consistent design system from day one saved countless hours later in development.

### 3. User Feedback is Gold
Every piece of feedback, positive or negative, helped shape the product into something people actually wanted to use.

## What's Next

Building Resumey.Pro was just the beginning. The experience has opened my eyes to the possibilities of combining design thinking with entrepreneurial spirit.

posts.title: The Art of Design Systems
posts.excerpt: Design systems are more than just component libraries. They're the foundation that enables teams to build consistent, scalable user experiences.
posts.content:
# The Art of Design Systems

Design systems have become the backbone of modern product development. But what makes a design system truly effective?

## More Than Components

A good design system is:
- **Consistent**: Visual and interaction patterns that users can predict
- **Scalable**: Components that work across different contexts
- **Accessible**: Built with inclusivity in mind from the start
- **Living**: Continuously evolving based on team needs

## Building for the Future

The best design systems I've worked with treat documentation as a first-class citizen. When developers can understand the 'why' behind design decisions, magic happens.

## Key Takeaways

1. Start small and grow organically
2. Invest in tooling and automation
3. Make adoption easy for your team
4. Measure success through usage, not just completion

posts.title: From Corporate to Startup: A Designer's Perspective
posts.excerpt: The transition from big company design to startup hustle taught me more about product thinking than any course could.
posts.content:
# From Corporate to Startup: A Designer's Perspective

Moving from a large corporation to the startup world was like learning to design all over again.

## Corporate vs Startup Design

### Corporate
- Extensive research phases
- Multiple stakeholder approvals
- Risk-averse decision making
- Resource abundance

### Startup
- Ship first, research later
- Direct access to users
- Comfortable with uncertainty
- Resource constraints breed creativity

## What I Learned

The biggest shift was learning to embrace uncertainty. In corporate environments, I was used to having all the answers before starting. In startups, you learn as you build.

## The Sweet Spot

The ideal approach combines the best of both worlds:
- Corporate's emphasis on research and process
- Startup's speed and user proximity

This hybrid approach has made me a more well-rounded designer and product thinker.
